input.code:
### Tensors
- Many real-world data has multiple *(>2)* interacting variables
    - Subject, verb, object triplets \\((s,v,o)\\)
    - Binary relation triplets \\((r_s, e_i, e_j)\\)
- 2D Matrix representation is an unnatural choice
- *Tensors* are the higher-order generalization of matrices
input.outputFormat:
Tensors

  • Many real-world data has multiple (>2) interacting variables
    • Subject, verb, object triplets (s,v,o)
    • Binary relation triplets (rs,ei,ej)
  • 2D Matrix representation is an unnatural choice
  • Tensors are the higher-order generalization of matrices

input.code:
### Notation
(Kolda and Bader, 2009)

- Vectors: boldface lower-case letters \\(\mathbf{v}\\)
- Matrices: boldface capital letters \\(\mathbf{M}\\)
- Tensors: Euler script letters \\(\mathcal{T}\\)
- Mode-\\(N\\) tensor is a multidimensional array with N indices

    \\(\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{R}^{I_1 \,\times\, I_2 \,\times\, \cdots\, \times\, I_N}\\)
input.outputFormat:
Notation

(Kolda and Bader, 2009)

  • Vectors: boldface lower-case letters v
  • Matrices: boldface capital letters M
  • Tensors: Euler script letters 

  • Mode-N tensor is a multidimensional array with N indices

    ∈ℝI1×I2×⋯×IN

Example Mode-3 Tensor

  • ∈ℝ|E|×|E|×|R|

input.code: ### Mode-3 Tensor Fibers - \\(\mathbf{t}_{\cdot jk}\\) is used to denote the mode-1 column fiber when fixing mode 2 to j and mode 3 to k - \\(\mathbf{t}_{i \cdot k}\\) mode-2 row fiber - \\(\mathbf{t}_{ij \cdot}\\) mode-3 tube fiber
input.outputFormat:
Mode-3 Tensor Fibers

  • t⋅jk is used to denote the mode-1 column fiber when fixing mode 2 to j and mode 3 to k
  • ti⋅k mode-2 row fiber
  • tij⋅ mode-3 tube fiber

input.code: ### Mode-3 Tensor Slices - \\(\mathbf{T}_{i\cdot\cdot}\\) denotes the horizontal slice when fixing the mode-1 index to i - \\(\mathbf{T}_{\cdot j \cdot}\\) vertical slice - \\(\mathbf{T}_{\cdot\cdot k}\\) lateral slice
input.outputFormat:
Mode-3 Tensor Slices

  • Ti⋅⋅ denotes the horizontal slice when fixing the mode-1 index to i
  • T⋅j⋅ vertical slice
  • T⋅⋅k lateral slice

input.code:
### Tensor Operations
- Mode-\\(N\\) tensor-vector product \\(\mathcal{T} \times_N \mathbf{v}\\)
    - Dot product of each mode-\\(N\\) fiber in \\(\mathcal{T}\\) with \\(\mathbf{v}\\)
- Mode-\\(N\\) tensor-matrix product \\(\mathcal{T} \times_N \mathbf{M}\\)
    - Matrix-vector product of each mode-\\(N\\) fiber in \\(\mathcal{T}\\) with \\(\mathbf{M}\\)
- Mode-\\(N\\) matricization \\(\mathbf{T}_{(N)}\\)
    - Arrange all mode-\\(N\\) fibers as columns
input.outputFormat:
Tensor Operations

  • Mode-N tensor-vector product ×Nv
    • Dot product of each mode-N fiber in  with v
  • Mode-N tensor-matrix product ×NM
    • Matrix-vector product of each mode-N fiber in  with M
  • Mode-N matricization T(N)
    • Arrange all mode-N fibers as columns

input.code: ### Tucker Decomposition (Tucker, 1966) - Given: \\(\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \,\times\, q \,\times\, r}\\) - \\(\mathcal{T} \approx \mathcal{G} \times_1 \mathbf{A} \times_2 \mathbf{B} \times_3 \mathbf{C}\\) - Where \\(\mathcal{G} \in \mathbb{R}^{N_1 \,\times\, N_2 \,\times\, N_3}\\), \\(\mathbf{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{N_1 \,\times\, p}\\), \\(\mathbf{B} \in \mathbb{R}^{N_2 \,\times\, q}\\), \\(\mathbf{C} \in \mathbb{R}^{N_3 \,\times\, r}\\) - \\(\mathcal{G}\\) is called *core tensor* - \\(\mathbf{A}\\), \\(\mathbf{B}\\) and \\(\mathbf{C}\\) are called *loading matrices* #### Example
input.outputFormat:
Tucker Decomposition

(Tucker, 1966)

  • Given: ∈ℝp×q×r
  • ≈×1A×2B×3C
    • Where ∈ℝN1×N2×N3, A∈ℝN1×p, B∈ℝN2×q, C∈ℝN3×r
    •  is called core tensor
    • A, B and C are called loading matrices

Example

input.code: ### Matrix Factorization as Tucker1 Decomposition
input.outputFormat: Matrix Factorization as Tucker1 Decomposition

input.code:
### CANDECOMP/PARAFAC
(Carroll and Chang, 1970; Harshman, 1970)

In PARAFAC the core tensor is restricted to be "diagonal"
input.outputFormat:
CANDECOMP/PARAFAC

(Carroll and Chang, 1970; Harshman, 1970)

In PARAFAC the core tensor is restricted to be "diagonal"

input.code:
### References I

- Kolda, Tamara G., and Brett W. Bader. "Tensor decompositions and applications." SIAM review 51.3 (2009): 455-500.
- Tucker, Ledyard R. "Some mathematical notes on three-mode factor analysis." Psychometrika 31.3 (1966): 279-311.
- Carroll, J. Douglas, and Jih-Jie Chang. "Analysis of individual differences in multidimensional scaling via an N-way generalization of “Eckart-Young” decomposition." Psychometrika 35.3 (1970): 283-319.
- Harshman, Richard A. "Foundations of the PARAFAC procedure: Models and conditions for an" explanatory" multi-modal factor analysis." (1970): 1-84.
APA
input.outputFormat:
References I

  • Kolda, Tamara G., and Brett W. Bader. "Tensor decompositions and applications." SIAM review 51.3 (2009): 455-500.
  • Tucker, Ledyard R. "Some mathematical notes on three-mode factor analysis." Psychometrika 31.3 (1966): 279-311.
  • Carroll, J. Douglas, and Jih-Jie Chang. "Analysis of individual differences in multidimensional scaling via an N-way generalization of “Eckart-Young” decomposition." Psychometrika 35.3 (1970): 283-319.
  • Harshman, Richard A. "Foundations of the PARAFAC procedure: Models and conditions for an" explanatory" multi-modal factor analysis." (1970): 1-84. APA
